canonical_explanation.text:
An ecosystem is a functional unit of nature where living organisms interact with one another and with the surrounding physical environment. It comprises two main components: abiotic (inorganic substances, organic compounds, climatic factors) and biotic (producers, consumers, decomposers). Productivity refers to the rate of biomass production. Gross Primary Productivity (GPP) is the total rate of photosynthesis, Net Primary Productivity (NPP) is GPP minus respiration losses, and secondary productivity is the rate of formation of new organic matter by consumers. Energy flows unidirectionally through trophic levels: producers, primary consumers, secondary consumers, and tertiary consumers. The 10% law (Lindeman's rule) states that only about 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next. Ecological pyramids may be of numbers, biomass, or energy; the pyramid of energy is always upright.

Decomposition is the breakdown of dead organic matter (detritus) by decomposers into simpler inorganic substances. The process involves fragmentation, leaching, catabolism, humification, and mineralisation. Nutrient cycling includes carbon cycle and phosphorus cycle, with gaseous and sedimentary pathways respectively. Ecological succession is the sequential, gradual change in species composition and community structure over time. Primary succession starts on bare or lifeless areas (e.g., bare rock, lava), while secondary succession occurs in areas where a community has been disturbed but soil and seeds remain. The final stable community in succession is called the climax community. Succession on bare rock begins with pioneer species like lichens (xerosere), while in water bodies it is called hydrarch succession.
rules: An ecosystem has abiotic (non-living) and biotic (producers, consumers, decomposers) components
GPP = total rate of photosynthesis; NPP = GPP − Respiration; NPP is available to consumers
10% law (Lindeman): only about 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next
Food chains are of two types: grazing food chain and detritus food chain
Ecological pyramids can be of numbers, biomass, or energy; energy pyramids are always upright
Decomposition involves fragmentation, leaching, catabolism, humification, and mineralisation
Humus is a dark amorphous substance highly resistant to microbial decomposition
Carbon cycle is a gaseous nutrient cycle; phosphorus cycle is a sedimentary nutrient cycle
Primary succession occurs on bare lifeless substrate; secondary succession occurs on disturbed areas with soil
Pioneer species in xerosere (on rock) are lichens; climax community is the stable end point of succession
Hydrarch succession: in water bodies, from submerged to floating to marsh to climax forest
Standing crop is the mass of living material (biomass) present at a given trophic level at a given time

questions.question_text: The functional unit of nature where living organisms interact with one another and with the physical environment is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An ecosystem is defined as a functional unit of nature where living organisms interact among themselves and with their surrounding physical environment. It includes both biotic and abiotic components functioning together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A community is a group of populations of different species living together. A population is a group of individuals of one species. A biome is a large geographical area with similar climate and vegetation. Ecosystem includes both living organisms and their physical environment.

questions.question_text: Net Primary Productivity (NPP) is defined as:

options.text: Rate of biomass production by consumers

questions.explanation_correct: Net Primary Productivity (NPP) is defined as Gross Primary Productivity (GPP) minus the respiration losses (R) of the producers. NPP = GPP − R. It represents the biomass available to consumers in an ecosystem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GPP is the total rate of photosynthesis. GPP plus respiration is not a meaningful ecological measure. Rate of biomass production by consumers is secondary productivity. NPP is specifically GPP minus respiration.

questions.question_text: According to the 10% law of energy transfer, if producers fix 10,000 J of energy, how much energy is available to primary consumers?
questions.explanation_correct: According to Lindeman's 10% law, only about 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next. If producers fix 10,000 J, primary consumers receive 10% of that, which is 1,000 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10,000 J is the energy at the producer level. 100 J would be the energy available to secondary consumers. 10 J would be at the tertiary consumer level. Primary consumers receive 10% of producer energy, i.e., 1,000 J.

questions.question_text: Which ecological pyramid is always upright in all ecosystems?

options.text: Both pyramid of numbers and energy

questions.explanation_correct: The pyramid of energy is always upright in all ecosystems because energy is progressively lost at each trophic level (due to respiration and heat loss). Energy can never increase at a higher trophic level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pyramid of numbers can be inverted (e.g., in a tree ecosystem). The pyramid of biomass can also be inverted (e.g., in aquatic ecosystems). Only the pyramid of energy is universally upright because of the unidirectional flow and loss of energy.

questions.question_text: In an aquatic ecosystem, the pyramid of biomass is often inverted. This is because:

options.text: Phytoplankton have a high turnover rate despite low standing biomass
Consumers do not feed on producers
Energy flow is reversed in aquatic ecosystems

questions.explanation_correct: In aquatic ecosystems, phytoplankton (producers) reproduce and turnover very rapidly, so at any given time their standing biomass is less than the biomass of zooplankton and fish (consumers). This results in an inverted pyramid of biomass despite the producers actually producing more biomass over time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Producers in aquatic ecosystems (phytoplankton) are actually much smaller than consumers. Consumers do feed on producers. Energy flow is never reversed. The inversion is due to the high turnover rate and low standing crop of phytoplankton.

questions.question_text: If the GPP of an ecosystem is 20,000 kcal/m²/year and the respiration of producers is 4,000 kcal/m²/year, the NPP would be:
questions.explanation_correct: NPP = GPP − Respiration = 20,000 − 4,000 = 16,000 kcal/m²/year. The net primary productivity represents the actual biomass available to consumers after accounting for the energy used by producers for their own respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 24,000 would result from adding GPP and respiration, which is incorrect. 4,000 is the respiration alone. 20,000 is the GPP, not NPP. NPP is always less than GPP because respiration is subtracted.

questions.question_text: A food chain that starts from dead organic matter and passes through detritivores is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A detritus food chain begins with dead organic matter (detritus) and involves detritivores and decomposers. For example: Dead leaves → Earthworm → Frog → Snake. In many ecosystems, the detritus food chain contributes more to energy flow than the grazing food chain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A grazing food chain starts from living plants (producers) and goes through herbivores and carnivores. There is no specific 'parasitic food chain' or 'predator food chain' as standard ecological terms. The chain starting from detritus is the detritus food chain.

questions.question_text: In a food chain: Grass → Grasshopper → Frog → Snake → Hawk, the organism at the third trophic level is:
questions.explanation_correct: Trophic levels are numbered from producers. Grass is at the first trophic level (producer), Grasshopper is second (primary consumer), Frog is third (secondary consumer), Snake is fourth (tertiary consumer), and Hawk is fifth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Grasshopper is at the second trophic level as a primary consumer. Snake is at the fourth trophic level. Hawk is at the fifth trophic level. The frog, feeding on grasshoppers, occupies the third trophic level as a secondary consumer.

questions.question_text: In a large tree ecosystem, the pyramid of numbers is inverted because:

options.text: The tree has the highest biomass
A single tree supports a large number of herbivorous insects, which in turn support more parasites
Energy is lost at each trophic level
Decomposers are more abundant than producers

questions.explanation_correct: In a tree ecosystem, a single large tree (one producer) supports hundreds of herbivorous insects (many primary consumers), which in turn support an even larger number of parasites and hyperparasites. The number of organisms increases at higher trophic levels, making the pyramid of numbers inverted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the tree does have the highest biomass, the question is about the pyramid of numbers, not biomass. Energy loss explains why the energy pyramid is upright, not why numbers are inverted. The inversion is because one tree supports progressively more organisms at higher levels.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Energy flow in an ecosystem is unidirectional.
Reason: Energy is lost as heat at each trophic level and cannot be recycled.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Energy flow in an ecosystem is indeed unidirectional — it flows from producers to consumers and never in the reverse direction. The reason correctly explains this: energy is lost as heat during metabolic processes at each trophic level and cannot be recycled or reused, unlike nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is a fundamental ecological principle. The reason is factually correct and directly explains why energy flow is one-way — because energy is dissipated as heat (second law of thermodynamics) and cannot be recycled.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has the highest net primary productivity per unit area?
questions.explanation_correct: Tropical rainforests have the highest net primary productivity per unit area among all ecosystems due to favourable conditions: high rainfall, warm temperatures, abundant light, and high species diversity. Their NPP can exceed 2,000 g/m²/year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oceans have a large total area but low per-unit-area productivity. Deserts have very low productivity due to limited water. Temperate grasslands have moderate productivity. Tropical rainforests are the most productive terrestrial ecosystems per unit area.

questions.question_text: Secondary productivity is the rate of formation of new organic matter by:
questions.explanation_correct: Secondary productivity refers to the rate of formation of new organic matter (biomass) by consumers (heterotrophs). It is the rate at which consumers assimilate and convert food energy into their own body mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Producers and autotrophs are responsible for primary productivity, not secondary. While decomposers are heterotrophs, secondary productivity specifically refers to biomass production by consumers (herbivores, carnivores). Producers contribute to primary productivity.

questions.question_text: The standing crop at each trophic level is measured as:

options.text: The energy flow per unit time
The mass of living material (biomass) at a given time

questions.explanation_correct: Standing crop is defined as the mass of living material (biomass) present at each trophic level at a particular time. It is expressed as biomass per unit area and represents the 'stock' of living organisms at that moment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy flow per unit time is productivity, not standing crop. Rate of decomposition relates to decomposer activity. Number of species describes species richness, not standing crop. Standing crop specifically measures the biomass present at a given time.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of processes in decomposition is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence of decomposition is: Fragmentation (breaking down of detritus by detritivores) → Leaching (water-soluble substances dissolve and seep into soil) → Catabolism (enzymatic degradation by decomposers) → Humification (formation of humus) → Mineralisation (release of inorganic nutrients from humus).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Catabolism does not occur first; detritus must be physically fragmented and soluble substances leached before enzymes can act. Mineralisation is the last step, not the first. The correct order reflects a progressive breakdown from large pieces to inorganic nutrients.

questions.question_text: Humus is described as a dark-coloured amorphous substance that is:
questions.explanation_correct: Humus is a dark-coloured, amorphous substance formed during humification. It is highly resistant to microbial action and undergoes decomposition at an extremely slow rate. Humus serves as a reservoir of nutrients and improves soil structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Humus is not easily decomposed — its resistance to decomposition is a defining characteristic. It is not rich in only phosphorus; it contains various nutrients. It is found in terrestrial soils, not exclusively in aquatic ecosystems.

questions.question_text: The phosphorus cycle is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The phosphorus cycle is a sedimentary nutrient cycle because the reservoir pool of phosphorus exists in rock and sediments (lithosphere), not in the atmosphere. Phosphorus enters the biotic component through weathering and soil absorption by plant roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The carbon and nitrogen cycles are gaseous cycles with atmospheric reservoirs. The phosphorus cycle does not have a significant atmospheric or gaseous phase. Its reservoir is in rocks and sediments, making it a sedimentary cycle.

questions.question_text: Primary succession occurs on:

options.text: Recently disturbed areas with intact soil
Bare, lifeless substrates like rocks or newly cooled lava
Areas after forest fires where soil remains

questions.explanation_correct: Primary succession begins in lifeless areas where there is no soil or living organisms, such as bare rock surfaces, newly cooled lava, or newly created sand dunes. The process starts with pioneer species like lichens that help in soil formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Areas with intact soil after disturbances undergo secondary succession. Forest fire areas and abandoned fields still have soil and seed banks, so they undergo secondary succession. Primary succession starts from scratch on completely barren substrates.

questions.question_text: The pioneer species in xerosere (succession on bare rock) are:
questions.explanation_correct: Lichens are the pioneer species in xerosere (primary succession on bare rock). They secrete acids that corrode the rock surface, creating a thin layer of soil. This enables the next seral community (mosses) to colonise.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mosses colonise after lichens have formed some soil. Grasses and shrubs appear in later stages of succession. Lichens are uniquely adapted to colonise bare rock surfaces as they can grow without soil.

questions.question_text: In the carbon cycle, carbon enters the biotic component mainly through:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbon dioxide from the atmosphere enters the biotic component primarily through photosynthesis, where producers fix atmospheric CO₂ into organic compounds. This is the main entry point for carbon into the living world.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Decomposition and respiration release carbon back to the atmosphere (CO₂). Combustion of fossil fuels also releases CO₂. Photosynthesis is the process that takes carbon from the abiotic to the biotic component.

questions.question_text: The final, stable community in ecological succession is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The climax community is the final, stable, self-sustaining community that is in equilibrium with the environment. It represents the endpoint of ecological succession and remains relatively unchanged until a major disturbance occurs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pioneer community is the first community to colonise a bare area. Seral communities are intermediate stages in succession. Transitional community is a general term for stages between pioneer and climax. The stable endpoint is the climax community.

questions.question_text: Mineralisation during decomposition results in the release of:
questions.explanation_correct: Mineralisation is the final step of decomposition where humus is further degraded by microbes, releasing inorganic nutrients (such as CO₂, water, and mineral ions like NH₄⁺, PO₄³⁻) into the soil. These nutrients are then available for uptake by plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Humus is formed during humification, not mineralisation. Complex organic compounds would be earlier intermediates. Detritus is the starting material for decomposition. Mineralisation specifically releases inorganic nutrients from humus.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a correct statement about ecological succession?

options.text: It is a sequential change in species composition
Secondary succession occurs faster than primary succession
Pioneer species in hydrarch succession are large trees
The climax community is in equilibrium with the environment

questions.explanation_correct: Pioneer species in hydrarch succession (succession in water) are small phytoplankton and submerged aquatic plants, not large trees. Large trees are part of the climax community, not the pioneer stage. This statement is incorrect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Succession is indeed a sequential change in species composition (A is correct). Secondary succession is faster because soil and seeds are already present (B is correct). The climax community is stable and in equilibrium (D is correct). Only C is incorrect.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Decomposition is faster in warm and moist environments.
Reason: Warm temperature and adequate moisture favour microbial activity.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Warm temperature increases enzyme activity of decomposers, and adequate moisture is essential for microbial growth and metabolism. Together, these conditions accelerate the rate of decomposition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is factually correct — decomposition is fastest in tropical regions with warm and moist conditions. The reason directly explains this by pointing to the conditions needed for decomposer activity. Both are true and causally linked.

questions.question_text: During succession on bare rock, the correct sequence of communities is:
questions.explanation_correct: In xerosere (succession on bare rock), the sequence is: Crustose lichens (pioneer) → Foliose lichens → Mosses → Herbs and grasses → Shrubs → Trees (climax). Lichens first weather the rock to form soil, allowing subsequent communities to establish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mosses cannot colonise bare rock directly — they need the thin soil created by lichens. Herbs and trees come even later. The correct sequence always starts with lichens as pioneers and progresses through increasingly complex plant communities.

questions.question_text: A food web differs from a food chain in that a food web:

options.text: Has only one path of energy flow
Consists of interconnected food chains with multiple feeding relationships

questions.explanation_correct: A food web consists of many interconnected food chains in an ecosystem, where organisms may feed on more than one species and may be consumed by more than one predator. It represents the complex network of feeding relationships more realistically than a single food chain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A food chain has one path of energy flow, not a food web. Food webs include producers. They do not always start with decomposers. The defining feature of a food web is the interconnection of multiple food chains.

questions.question_text: Producers in an ecosystem include:
questions.explanation_correct: Producers (autotrophs) are organisms that can synthesise organic food from inorganic materials using sunlight. Green plants, algae, and cyanobacteria are producers that fix carbon dioxide through photosynthesis and form the base of all food chains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbivores and carnivores are consumers. Fungi and most bacteria are decomposers or consumers (heterotrophs). Producers are autotrophic organisms — primarily green plants and photosynthetic algae in most ecosystems.

questions.question_text: Which of the following processes returns CO₂ to the atmosphere in the carbon cycle?
questions.explanation_correct: Respiration by living organisms and combustion of fossil fuels both release CO₂ back into the atmosphere. Decomposition of dead organic matter also releases CO₂. These are the main processes that return carbon to the atmospheric pool.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Photosynthesis removes CO₂ from the atmosphere (fixes it). Nitrogen fixation converts atmospheric N₂ to ammonia. Phosphorus weathering involves phosphate, not carbon. Respiration and combustion are the key processes releasing CO₂ back to the atmosphere.

questions.question_text: Leaching during decomposition involves:

options.text: Breaking down of detritus into smaller pieces by detritivores
Water-soluble inorganic nutrients dissolving and moving into the soil
Enzymatic conversion of detritus into simpler compounds

questions.explanation_correct: Leaching is the process by which water-soluble inorganic nutrients dissolve in water and seep into the soil through percolation. It is the second step of decomposition after fragmentation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breaking detritus into smaller pieces is fragmentation. Enzymatic conversion is catabolism. Formation of humus is humification. Leaching specifically involves the dissolution and downward movement of soluble substances into the soil.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly represents the 10% energy transfer in a food chain with four trophic levels, if the energy at the producer level is 100,000 J?
questions.explanation_correct: According to the 10% law, each trophic level receives only 10% of the energy from the previous level. So T1 (producers) = 100,000 J; T2 (primary consumers) = 10,000 J; T3 (secondary consumers) = 1,000 J; T4 (tertiary consumers) = 100 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B shows 50% transfer. Option C shows 90% transfer. Option D shows 1% transfer. The 10% law means each successive trophic level gets one-tenth of the energy of the level below it.

questions.question_text: Detritivores differ from decomposers in that detritivores:

options.text: Secrete enzymes onto dead matter externally
Physically break down detritus by ingestion and fragmentation

questions.explanation_correct: Detritivores (such as earthworms, millipedes, and dung beetles) physically ingest and break down detritus into smaller fragments. Decomposers (fungi and bacteria) secrete enzymes externally to chemically break down organic matter. Detritivores aid decomposition through fragmentation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secreting enzymes externally is the role of decomposers, not detritivores. Detritivores act on dead matter, not living organisms. Detritivores are typically macroscopic (visible organisms). The key difference is physical fragmentation by detritivores versus chemical breakdown by decomposers.

questions.question_text: Secondary succession is generally faster than primary succession because:

options.text: Soil with seeds, nutrients, and some organisms is already present
There are no predators in the area
Climax community is the same as pioneer community

questions.explanation_correct: Secondary succession occurs in areas where soil, seed banks, and remnants of biological communities already exist (e.g., after a forest fire or flood). The presence of soil and propagules accelerates the process compared to primary succession, which starts on bare rock without any soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pioneer species are present in secondary succession too — they are just different from those in primary succession. Predators may or may not be present. The climax community is the final stage, not the same as the pioneer community. Existing soil and seeds are the key reason for faster succession.

questions.question_text: The reservoir for the phosphorus cycle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The reservoir pool for the phosphorus cycle is rocks and natural phosphate deposits (lithosphere). Phosphorus is released through weathering and erosion. Unlike carbon and nitrogen, phosphorus does not have a gaseous phase and cycles through sedimentary pathways.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The atmosphere is the reservoir for carbon (CO₂) and nitrogen (N₂) cycles, not phosphorus. The hydrosphere and living organisms are exchange pools, not reservoir pools. The primary reservoir for phosphorus is in rocks and sediments.

questions.question_text: Fragmentation during decomposition is carried out by:
questions.explanation_correct: Fragmentation is the first step of decomposition where detritivores (such as earthworms, millipedes, and woodlice) break down detritus into smaller particles. This increases the surface area available for microbial decomposition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bacteria and fungi carry out catabolism (enzymatic degradation). Producers synthesise food. Herbivores consume living plants. Fragmentation is specifically performed by detritivores that physically break down dead organic matter.

questions.question_text: In which ecosystem is the detritus food chain more important than the grazing food chain?
questions.explanation_correct: In a forest ecosystem, a large proportion of the energy flows through the detritus food chain because much of the net primary production (leaves, twigs, bark) falls as dead organic matter (litter) and is consumed by detritivores and decomposers rather than by herbivores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In grasslands, much biomass is consumed by grazers, so the grazing food chain dominates. In aquatic ecosystems, phytoplankton are consumed by zooplankton (grazing chain). In forests, the large amount of leaf litter makes the detritus food chain predominant.

questions.question_text: Hydrarch succession begins in:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrarch succession is primary succession that begins in a water body (aquatic habitat) and progresses through stages of submerged, floating, reed-swamp, marsh-meadow, woodland, and finally a climax forest community. It proceeds from water to drier conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Succession on bare rock is called xerosere. Sand dune succession is psammosere. Abandoned farmland undergoes secondary succession. Hydrarch succession specifically starts in aquatic environments.

questions.question_text: Organisms that obtain energy by feeding on dead organic matter are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Saprotrophs (decomposers) are organisms such as fungi and bacteria that obtain energy by breaking down dead organic matter (detritus). They secrete digestive enzymes externally and absorb the digested nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Autotrophs make their own food. Herbivores feed on living plants. Primary consumers are herbivores. Organisms feeding on dead organic matter are saprotrophs or decomposers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about nutrient cycling is correct?

options.text: The carbon cycle is a sedimentary cycle
Nutrients are recycled between biotic and abiotic components
The phosphorus cycle has a significant gaseous phase

questions.explanation_correct: Unlike energy which flows unidirectionally, nutrients are recycled between the biotic and abiotic components of an ecosystem. This recycling of nutrients through the ecosystem is called biogeochemical cycling or nutrient cycling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nutrients are recycled, not unidirectional. The carbon cycle is a gaseous cycle (not sedimentary). The phosphorus cycle does not have a significant gaseous phase — it is sedimentary. The correct statement is that nutrients cycle between living and non-living components.

questions.question_text: The 10% law of energy transfer was proposed by:
questions.explanation_correct: The 10% law of energy transfer was proposed by Raymond Lindeman (1942). It states that only about 10% of the energy available at one trophic level is transferred to the next higher trophic level. This is also called Lindeman's trophic efficiency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Odum made major contributions to ecosystem ecology. Tansley coined the term 'ecosystem'. Haeckel coined the term 'ecology'. The 10% law specifically was given by Lindeman based on his studies of Cedar Bog Lake.

questions.question_text: Which of the following conditions would slow down the rate of decomposition?
questions.explanation_correct: Decomposition is slowed by low temperature (reduces enzyme activity) and anaerobic conditions (limits aerobic decomposer activity). These conditions inhibit microbial metabolism. This is why decomposition is very slow in cold regions and waterlogged soils.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Warm and moist environments accelerate decomposition. Oxygen availability promotes aerobic decomposition. Detritivores enhance fragmentation and thus decomposition. Low temperature and lack of oxygen both inhibit decomposer activity.

questions.question_text: The term 'ecosystem' was coined by:
questions.explanation_correct: The term 'ecosystem' was coined by A.G. Tansley in 1935. He defined it as the system resulting from the integration of all living and non-living factors of the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: E.P. Odum is the 'father of modern ecosystem ecology'. Charles Elton proposed the concepts of food chains and ecological niches. Lindeman proposed the 10% law. The term 'ecosystem' was coined by Tansley.

questions.question_text: In the carbon cycle, the largest reservoir of carbon on Earth is:
questions.explanation_correct: The oceans are the largest reservoir of carbon on Earth, containing dissolved carbon dioxide and carbonates. About 71% of the total carbon is found in the oceans. The atmosphere, fossil fuels, and living organisms contain comparatively smaller amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The atmosphere contains only about 1% of Earth's total carbon. Living organisms and forests are exchange pools, not the largest reservoir. Oceans store the majority of carbon as dissolved CO₂ and carbonate/bicarbonate ions.

questions.question_text: In a pond ecosystem, phytoplankton represent the:
questions.explanation_correct: Phytoplankton are microscopic photosynthetic organisms that form the base of aquatic food chains. They are the primary producers in pond ecosystems, fixing solar energy through photosynthesis and converting inorganic substances into organic food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Primary consumers are zooplankton that feed on phytoplankton. Secondary consumers feed on primary consumers. Decomposers break down dead organic matter. Phytoplankton, being photosynthetic, are the producers in aquatic ecosystems.

questions.question_text: The process of conversion of dead organic matter into simpler inorganic compounds by enzymes of decomposers is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Catabolism is the enzymatic degradation of detritus into simpler inorganic compounds by bacteria and fungi. The decomposers secrete extracellular enzymes that break down complex organic molecules into simpler substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fragmentation is the physical breakdown by detritivores. Leaching is the washing out of water-soluble substances. Humification is the formation of humus. Catabolism specifically refers to the enzymatic chemical breakdown by decomposers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the relationship between GPP, NPP, and respiration (R)?
questions.explanation_correct: The relationship is GPP = NPP + R, or equivalently, NPP = GPP − R. Gross Primary Productivity is the total photosynthesis. Part of this is used by producers for their own respiration (R), and the remainder is the Net Primary Productivity (NPP) available to consumers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NPP = GPP + R would mean net productivity exceeds gross, which is impossible. R = NPP + GPP and GPP = NPP × R are mathematically incorrect relationships. The correct formula is GPP = NPP + R.

questions.question_text: A forest destroyed by fire undergoes secondary succession. The first organisms to recolonise are most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: In secondary succession after a fire, grasses and herbs are typically the first to recolonise because the soil already exists with seeds, spores, and nutrients. Unlike primary succession which starts with lichens on bare rock, secondary succession begins with fast-growing herbaceous plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Large trees are late-successional species. Lichens are pioneer species in primary succession on bare rock, not secondary succession. Large mammals depend on vegetation for food and habitat. Grasses and herbs colonise quickly from existing seed banks in the soil.

questions.question_text: Omnivores occupy multiple trophic levels because they:

options.text: Feed on both plants and animals at different trophic levels
Are always at the top of the food chain
Do not participate in food chains

questions.explanation_correct: Omnivores eat both plant material and animals, which means they can function as primary consumers (when eating plants) and as secondary or higher consumers (when eating animals). This places them at multiple trophic levels simultaneously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Organisms that only feed on producers are herbivores, not omnivores. Omnivores are not always at the top of the food chain. They do participate in food chains. Their distinguishing feature is feeding at more than one trophic level.

questions.question_text: Which of the following seral stages is NOT correctly placed in the xerosere sequence?
questions.explanation_correct: In xerosere, the correct sequence is: Lichen → Moss → Herb → Shrub → Tree. The shrub stage comes AFTER the herb stage, not before it. Hence, option C is incorrectly placed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crustose lichens are indeed the pioneer species (A is correct). Mosses come after lichens (B is correct). Trees form the climax community (D is correct). Only C is wrong — herbs precede shrubs in the succession sequence.

questions.question_text: The carbon cycle is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The carbon cycle is a gaseous biogeochemical cycle because its reservoir pool exists primarily in the atmosphere as carbon dioxide (CO₂). Carbon cycles between the atmosphere, living organisms, oceans, and fossil fuels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sedimentary cycles have reservoirs in rocks/sediments (like the phosphorus cycle). The hydrological cycle involves water movement. The carbon cycle's primary reservoir is atmospheric CO₂, making it a gaseous cycle.

questions.question_text: Consider a grassland ecosystem where a large portion of grass biomass is consumed by herbivores. The pyramid of biomass in this ecosystem would most likely be:
questions.explanation_correct: In a grassland ecosystem, the pyramid of biomass is upright because the biomass of producers (grasses) is always greater than the combined biomass of primary consumers (herbivores), which in turn is greater than that of secondary consumers. Even though herbivores consume a large portion, the standing crop of grass remains higher.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inverted biomass pyramids are characteristic of aquatic ecosystems where phytoplankton have high turnover. Spindle and diamond shapes are not standard pyramid types. In terrestrial grasslands, the biomass pyramid is upright.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about humification is correct?

options.text: It is the first step of decomposition
It results in the formation of humus, a dark-coloured resistant substance
It is carried out by detritivores

questions.explanation_correct: Humification leads to the accumulation of a dark-coloured, amorphous substance called humus that is highly resistant to microbial action. Humus undergoes very slow decomposition and serves as a nutrient reservoir in the soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fragmentation is the first step, not humification. Mineralisation, not humification, releases inorganic nutrients. Humification is a chemical process carried out by soil microbes, not detritivores. Humification specifically produces humus.
